Q: Can the Safety Matrix Editor be installed on an office PC, and for what purpose?
A: Yes, installation on an office PC is possible to facilitate the design of safety features.

Q: What are the installation steps for Safety Matrix on an office PC?
A: Step: Install the Safety Matrix Editor on the office PC for the purpose of designing safety features.

Q: What component is selected for installation when choosing the 'Runtime' package for Safety Matrix on an OS client?
A: The 'Runtime' package includes Safety Matrix Viewer V6.2 SP2 for OS client installation.

Q: What components are selected for installation when choosing the 'Engineering' package for S7 F Systems on the ES?
A: Selected components under 'Engineering' are: 1) S7 F Systems V6.2 Upd1, 2) S7 F Systems HMI V6.2, 3) S7 F Systems Lib V1_3 SP2, 4) S7 F ConfigurationPack V5.5 SP13, 5) S7 F Device Integration Pack V6.2 Upd1.

Q: What components are selected for installation when choosing the 'Engineering' package for Safety Matrix?
A: Safety Matrix Engineering Tool V6.2 SP2, Safety Matrix Viewer V6.2 SP2, and Safety Matrix AS-OS Engineering V6.2 SP3 Upd1.

Q: What is required before installing Safety Matrix Engineering?
A: The prerequisite for installing Safety Matrix Engineering is having S7 F System of a corresponding version already installed.

Q: What is the importance of checking PCS 7 support for F-modules during installation?
A: This check guarantees that the installed F-modules are compatible with PCS 7, avoiding operational issues.

Q: What is the procedure for installing S7 F Systems on an OS client?
A: To install on an OS client, execute SETUP.EXE, choose 'Runtime', and proceed with S7 F Systems HMI V6.2 installation.

Q: What should be checked during an update installation of S7 F Systems according to the note?
A: Two checks are recommended: 1) whether to update S7 F Systems Lib or keep the old version, and 2) PCS 7's support for the F-modules in use.

Q: What version of S7 F Systems Lib is supported as of S7 F Systems V6.2?
A: Version V1_3 or later.

Q: How is the actual response time of a safety function characterized?
A: Characterized by being within the bounds of minimum and maximum response times.

Q: What are the five sections into which the path of a signal is divided in S7ftime.xlsm?
A: First section is Input, covering the sensor to user program duration.

Q: What is the definition of response time in the context of safety functions?
A: Response time is defined as the duration from input signal detection to output signal change.

Q: What is the minimum value for the TIMEOUT parameter in the F_RBO and F_R_R F-FBs for data exchange between F-shutdown groups?
A: TIMEOUT must be no less than 500 ms in the configuration of F_RBO and F_R_R F-FBs.

Q: What is the process safety time?
A: It's the time the process can be left uncontrolled without creating danger.

Q: What must be assumed when configuring a plant in terms of response time?
A: The worst-case scenario, i.e., maximum response time, must be considered.

Q: What must the maximum response time of a safety function be in relation to the process safety time?
A: A safety function's maximum response time needs to be below the process safety time.

Q: What parameters are needed to calculate the 'TIMEOUT' parameter for the F_RBO and F_R_R F-FBs?
A: The calculation requires TCImax1 (send block's max cycle time) and TCImax2 (receive block's max cycle time).

Q: What tool can be used to determine the lowest value for the timeout?
A: Use S7ftime.xls to calculate the minimum required timeout.

Q: Where can the values for TCImax1 and TCImax2 be found?
A: The values are located in the MAX_CYC input of the F_CYC_CO-OBxx F function block within the @F_CycCo-OBxx chart.

Q: How is the maximum reaction time calculated in the process?
A: It involves picking the pertinent variants in each part and inputting their values.

Q: How many variants are possible for the Input/Output section based on the hardware configuration?
A: Depending on the hardware, there can be up to five different variants.

Q: What are the two main processing steps mentioned for the F CPUs?
A: They involve the cycle time and runtime evaluation of the F program.

Q: What determines the variant used in each section of the process?
A: The choice of variant depends on how the system's hardware is configured.

Q: What does the 'Cycle time and runtime of F program' refer to in the processing steps?
A: This denotes the duration of one cycle and the overall execution time of the F program.

Q: What is optional in the F CPU-to-F CPU communication step?
A: It's optional to send a signal to a second F-CPU during this step.

Q: What is the final step in the described process?
A: Outputting the runtime from user program to actuator is the last step.

Q: What is the purpose of the F CPU-to-F CPU communication step in the process?
A: Its purpose is facilitating optional signal transmission from one F CPU to another.

Q: What is the significance of the 'Output: Runtime from user program to actuator' step?
A: It marks the delivery of the program's runtime result to the actuator.

Q: Why might different variants be used in each section of the process?
A: Variants are used to match the process with the hardware's capabilities.

Q: How is the discrepancy time (TDIS) set according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Through hardware configuration of the F-signal module, specifically when 1oo2 evaluation is chosen.

Q: How is the response time calculated for the EM 8 F-DI Ex NAMUR module with 1oo2 evaluation and 'Provide last valid value' discrepancy behavior?
A: For this configuration, add internal processing, input delay, discrepancy time, and sensor test/start-up durations.

Q: How is the response time calculated for the F-AI 6 x 0/4 ... 20 mA HART module with 1oo2 evaluation in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Sum of twice the conversion cycle time (filtered and unfiltered) and the discrepancy time.

Q: Under what conditions should a discrepancy time of 0 be entered for a module in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: If no 1oo2 evaluation is performed or if a value of 0 is output immediately upon discrepancy.

Q: What are the TWCDT and TOFDT for the DI 24 x DC 24 V 6ES7326-1BK02-0AB0 module as per the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: TWCDT: 32 ms (max internal processing + input delay + short-circuit test). TOFDT: 31 ms (1oo1) or 29 ms (1oo2).

Q: What determines the maximum response times TWCDT and TOFDT in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Module-specific manuals, like those for S7-300 ET 200M, provide these maximum response times.

Q: What is the cycle time for the EM 4 F-DO Ex 17.4V/40mA module according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The base cycle time is 7 ms, with additional time depending on the light test configuration.

Q: What is the delay time assumed for TSensor_DLY/TActuator_DLY in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: In the absence of specific device data, 100 ms is used for TSensor_DLY/TActuator_DLY.

Q: What is the effect of an error in the sensor supply test on the response time for the EM 8 F-DI Ex NAMUR module with 'Provide last valid value' discrepancy behavior?
A: The response time is extended due to the necessity of repeating the failed sensor supply test.

Q: What parameters affect the response time of the EM 8 F-DI Ex NAMUR module in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Several factors: processing time, delay, discrepancy time, and whether sensor tests are activated.

Q: How is the cycle time calculated in the provided example?
A: The example shows cycle time as 7 ms plus 3 ms equals 10 ms.

Q: Is processing in the 2nd CPU mandatory according to the text?
A: According to the text, processing in the second CPU is not required; it's optional.

Q: What is the document identifier for the Operating Manual mentioned?
A: Document ID: A5E43228905-AA.

Q: What is the maximum dark test readback time mentioned in the example?
A: In the example, it's stated as 10 ms for the max. dark test readback time.

Q: What is the maximum response time with a channel error for 4 active channels at 50 Hz interference frequency?
A: Under specified conditions, the maximum response time with a channel error reaches 218 milliseconds.

Q: What is the response time in the example given?
A: The response time is calculated to be 19 ms in the example.

Q: What is the title of the compendium mentioned in the text?
A: The compendium is titled 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'.

Q: What is the typical response time formula when no errors are present?
A: Typical response time is the product of conversion cycle time and filter.

Q: What section discusses monitoring times and system response times in the safety program configuration?
A: 7.11 Monitoring times and system response times

Q: Where should the discrepancy time be entered according to the text?
A: Parameter TDIS is the designated entry point for discrepancy time.

Q: How do the response times from sensor to actuator differ based on the presence of faults/errors?
A: Differences are noted as 661 ms (normal), 1948 ms (faulty), and 3771 ms (any condition).

Q: How does CPU-to-CPU communication affect the calculation process?
A: If CPU-to-CPU communication is occurring, the time parameterized at the TIMEOUT input of the send and receive blocks is required for calculation.

Q: What are the three response times provided by S7ftime.xls for the max response time from the input terminal to the output terminal of the F-IIO?
A: 461 ms if there are no faults/errors, 1748 ms if there is a fault/error, and 3571 ms for any run time of the standard or fault-tolerant system.

Q: What are the two different variants of F-shutdown groups mentioned in the text?
A: The text mentions two variants: one with a single F-shutdown group and another with two F-shutdown groups in the signal flow.

Q: What determines a Safety Matrix's identity as per the text?
A: Version number, file version, and signature are the determining factors.

Q: What is the significance of the lower group in the result section?
A: The lower group accounts for the delay times of the sensor and actuator in its calculations.

Q: What is the title and publication detail of the compendium mentioned in the text?
A: Title: 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)', details: Operating Manual, 04/2018, A5E43228905-AA.

Q: What parameters are needed for the calculation according to the text?
A: Parameters such as TCI, TCImax.proj., TFPROG, and TIMEOUT are essential for the mentioned calculations.

Q: What should be checked regarding the calculated times from S7ftime.xls?
A: Make sure the calculated response times are appropriate for your process.

Q: Where can one find information on creating and configuring a Safety Matrix according to the text?
A: The manual 'SIMATIC Industrial Software Safety Matrix' provides the needed information, accessible online.

Q: How can differences in version number and signature be detected during online access?
A: Messages are generated during online access when comparisons show version or signature discrepancies.

Q: How can the EN_SWC input be permanently set to '1' in the Safety Matrix block?
A: An F_NOT block's output interconnection allows the EN_SWC input to be fixed at '1'.

Q: How is a Safety Matrix documented according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: A text file containing all matrix configurations is produced via the documentation menu option for printing or saving.

Q: What are the consequences of downloading a matrix with modified version number and signature to the CPU?
A: A matrix with changed version and signature requires recompilation and download of the OS server and single stations.

Q: What does the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)' specify about the Safety Matrix's operation?
A: The document explains enabling the Safety Matrix in the CFC and the operator permissions essential for OS functionality.

Q: What happens when the matrix is saved in terms of version and signature?
A: The act of saving the matrix results in a version change, including the minor version, thereby modifying the signature.

Q: What is required to enable the operation of the Safety Matrix in the CFC?
A: A '1' signal at the EN_SWC input in the CFC is required to enable the Safety Matrix's operation.

Q: What is the purpose of the F-password in the online mode of the ES?
A: The F-password is used in online mode to verify operator authorization for access protection.

Q: What is the significance of the EN_SWC input being overwritten when the Safety Matrix is transferred to the CFC?
A: To maintain the EN_SWC input's '1' setting, overwriting must be avoided during the transfer to CFC.

Q: What permissions are required for operating an OS with the Safety Matrix?
A: For OS operation, one must have the operator permissions as configured in the Safety Matrix Engineering Tool.

Q: How can you duplicate a matrix in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)' to maintain the same settings?
A: Export the desired matrix as a source from the matrix folder, rename it, then import it back into the matrix folder using the 'Import CEM' button.

Q: How can you ensure that as much information as possible is retained when printing a matrix from the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: To retain maximum information, ensure all 'General' tab options are enabled under 'View > Adapt > Layout' prior to printing.

Q: How do you insert a new matrix into a new shutdown group according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: For a new matrix in a new shutdown group, pick an unused cyclic interrupt OB, compile the matrix, and arrange its runtime groups within the chosen OB.

Q: What additional runtime groups does the compiler create when compiling the S7 program in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: For each new shutdown group, the compiler produces @F_IN_<OBNr>_xx and @F_OUT_<OBNr>_xx runtime groups during S7 program compilation.

Q: What are the requirements for a user to initiate and confirm a specific action in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: To perform both initiation and confirmation, a user's permissions must include 'Initiator' (100) and 'Confirmer' (101) levels.

Q: What is a key limitation of the printout from the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)' regarding acceptance documents?
A: The printout cannot serve as an acceptance document because it misses critical information such as signatures and cyclic interrupt OB details.

Q: What is the significance of the F_PSG_M block in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The F_PSG_M block is placed at the end of a new matrix runtime group to create the required shutdown group.

Q: What must be done to transfer changes from the Safety Matrix engineering tool correctly in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: For correct change application, the matrix cycle time must reflect the current OB setting (e.g., 300 ms for OB 37) during transfer.

Q: What must be ensured when assigning F-module drivers to shutdown groups in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: To prevent errors, ensure every signal within an F-signal module is assigned to a single shutdown group.

Q: Why is it important to divide into shutdown groups at the start of configuration in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Early division into shutdown groups minimizes extensive reconfiguration work later by ensuring F-signal modules are correctly assigned from the beginning.

Q: From which version can certain channel driver types be incorporated into the Safety Matrix?
A: Incorporation of specified channel driver types is possible from Safety Matrix V6.2 onward, utilizing a 'customer-specific' setting.

Q: How is an S7-400 F/FH system protected when operated as a safety system?
A: Dual password protection is implemented to safeguard the S7-400 F/FH system against unauthorized access.

Q: How is the operation of the safety matrix enabled in the CFC?
A: By applying a '1' signal at the EN_SWC input, either through logic or interconnection to the input channel driver of a key switch.

Q: What are the requirements for operating an OS with the Safety Matrix Engineering Tool?
A: Operator permissions configured in the Safety Matrix Engineering Tool are necessary for OS operation.

Q: What function can be enabled when transferring the matrix to the project for imported channel drivers?
A: The 'Imported channel drivers (IEA support)' function can be enabled to interconnect not just the process value and its status but also maintenance and acknowledgment inputs.

Q: What is emphasized in the 'Operational procedures' section of the Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)?
A: Emphasis is placed on the critical nature of operational procedures in maintaining safety during plant work.

Q: What is recommended if parameter changes are needed for F-channel drivers?
A: For necessary parameter adjustments, it's advised to establish a process tag (CFC) for the signal in question.

Q: What is the purpose of internal F-channel drivers in the Safety Matrix?
A: Internal F-channel drivers are created by the Safety Matrix during transfer in a 'Driver chart' and interconnected with the Safety Matrix to ensure safety functions are properly executed.

Q: What must be done before making changes to safety-related parts of a plant?
A: A risk assessment must be conducted to evaluate the change's impact and methodology, especially if performed during operation.

Q: Why must certain I/Os not be interconnected for external F-channel drivers?
A: Leaving certain I/Os unconnected ensures that the Safety Matrix's integration of external drivers does not disrupt their existing logic.

Q: How are new runtime groups handled when adding a new CFC in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The system auto-generates a runtime group matching the new CFC's name upon addition.

Q: How can you ensure the offline and online programs are identical before a CFC change in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The manual suggests opening an AS chart in the CFC editor and entering online mode to compare offline and online programs.

Q: How can you measure the runtimes of OBs in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Install blocks TIME_BEG and TIME_END in the OBs and check TM_DIFF_TI at TIME_END block.

Q: What action is required for empty F-runtime groups in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Empty F-runtime groups should be eliminated to maintain program cleanliness and efficiency.

Q: What is the procedure for checking H parameters in fault-tolerant systems as per 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Inspect the 'H Parameters' tab within CPU Object Properties to assess fault-tolerant system settings.

Q: What must be checked before making changes to ensure CPU utilization is optimal according to 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The manual advises checking CPU memory and cycle time utilization prior to making changes.

Q: What must be done before downloading changes during operation according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)' specifies that safety mode on the AS should be turned off for downloading changes and turned back on post-download.

Q: What precaution should be taken before downloading hardware configuration changes with HCiR in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Ensure no system errors are present before downloading hardware configuration changes with HCiR.

Q: What sequence must be followed to make changes to the standard or fail-safe program in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Change CFC, check, compile, download, perform offline/online comparison, test, and document.

Q: What tool is recommended for comparing two project versions in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The 'Version Cross Manager' serves as a tool for comparing current and backed-up project versions.

Q: How can changes in the safety program be tracked according to the compendium?
A: The compendium recommends backing up projects and employing the 'Version Cross Manager' to compare and track changes in the safety program.

Q: How can you document the current safety program according to the compendium?
A: Documentation can be achieved by printing the safety program and hardware configurations directly from the 'Edit Safety Program' dialog.

Q: How can you test your functions according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The manual recommends two methods: simulation with S7-PLCSIM or actual testing on a test AS, both initiated by the 'Load to test AS' function.

Q: What checklists are available for system documentation in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The 'Process Safety – Configuration' and 'Process Safety – Verification/Testing' checklists are provided for system documentation.

Q: What does CiR allow you to do with F signal modules in an ET 200M rack?
A: The CiR feature enables the addition or removal of F signal modules, restricted to the ET 200M rack's terminal slots.

Q: What is required to download CFC charts in S7-PLCSIM V5.4 and higher?
A: In S7-PLCSIM V5.4+, the configured CPU password, not the default 'plcsim', must be entered to proceed with downloading CFC charts.

Q: What is the purpose of the 'Optimize run sequence' function in the context of F-runtime groups?
A: F-runtime groups are not affected by the 'Optimize run sequence' function, as they are specifically excluded from such optimizations.

Q: What is the role of the program signature in the safety program?
A: The program signature identifies the safety program and changes with any modifications, serving as a quick indicator of alterations.

Q: What is the significance of the signature value of a fail-safe signal module?
A: It serves as a fingerprint for the safety settings of fail-safe signal modules, requiring updates post any HW configuration changes.

Q: What must be done before downloading changes to the safety program?
A: Deactivation of safety mode and a consistency test are prerequisites for downloading changes to the safety program, followed by reactivation.

Q: How can access to the ES be restricted according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: By placing the ES in a restricted area and employing password and screen saver protections, as per the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'.

Q: How can authorized persons reset access authorization for the F-CPU before exiting the ES based on the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: By selecting 'CPU > Access authorization > Cancel' or closing all applications in the SIMATIC Manager.

Q: How is access protection activated in the SIMATIC Manager according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Through the 'Options > Access Protection' menu with the selected project node.

Q: What are the purposes of the CPU password in the S7 F/FH system according to the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: As per the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)', the CPU password prevents accidental downloads and ensures the correct program is loaded.

Q: What are the two passwords that protect an S7 F/FH system in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: An S7 F/FH system is protected by a CPU password and a safety program password, as detailed in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'.

Q: What does the safety program password protect in the S7 F/FH system as mentioned in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: It protects the fail-safe user program and the parameters of the signal modules and possibly the CPU.

Q: What happens the first time access protection is activated in the SIMATIC Manager based on the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: Upon first activation, the project is updated to a format that older STEP 7 versions cannot open.

Q: What is required to set up access protection with SIMATIC Logon as per the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)' specifies the need for SIMATIC Logon Service version 1.3 SP1 or newer.

Q: What is the significance of the SIMATIC Logon Service version for access protection in 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)' specifies that only SIMATIC Logon Service V1.3 SP1 and above supports access protection.

Q: What organizational measures are suggested to protect the safety program in the 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)'?
A: The 'Compendium Part B - Process Safety (V9.0)' advises ensuring only authorized personnel know the passwords and resetting access rights upon ES exit.

Q: As of S7 F Systems V6.2, what events from S7 F/FH Systems are logged when using SIMATIC Logon as of V1.3 and STEP 7 as of V5.5.4 Upd9?
A: It records instances of safety mode activation/deactivation and safety program password modifications.

Q: Can you list the events logged by S7 F Systems V6.2 under specific conditions?
A: Specifically, it logs when safety mode is enabled or disabled and when the safety program's password is changed.

Q: How are projects with activated access protection displayed when a multiproject is opened without prior authentication?
A: Projects with activated access protection appear grayed-out.

Q: What are the prerequisites for logging certain events from S7 F/FH Systems?
A: Prerequisites include SIMATIC Logon from V1.3 onward and STEP 7 from V5.5.4 Upd9 onward.

Q: What happens if you try to open a multiproject without authenticating first?
A: Projects that have access protection enabled show as grayed-out without prior authentication.

Q: What indicates that a project within a multiproject has activated access protection?
A: The project is displayed grayed-out when the multiproject is opened without prior authentication.

Q: What is the first step in accessing the SIMATIC Logon Service?
A: The first step is logging on to the SIMATIC Logon Service.

Q: What version of PCS 7 corresponds to STEP 7 as of V5.5.4 Upd9?
A: For STEP 7 V5.5.4 Upd9, the matching PCS 7 version is V8.1.

Q: When is the project password set in the SIMATIC Logon Service process?
A: The password for the project is configured when access protection is first activated.

Q: Who is automatically entered as the first project administrator when activating access protection?
A: The Windows user activating access protection is automatically entered as the first project administrator.
